awd_titl_txt: EFRI NewLAW: Dynamic Elastic media: Passive and Active non-Reciprocal Theory, Experiment and Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Two of the most fundamental concepts in wave propagation and signal transmission are the closely related principles of reciprocity and time-reversal symmetry.  Reciprocity requires that a wave traveling in one direction can just as well travel in the opposite direction, while time-reversal symmetry provides the same relationship when time is reversed.   Recent advances in engineering have shown that either or both principles can be violated under special conditions, for instance in the presence of moving fluid and solid elements.  This award supports fundamental research to demonstrate novel methods for realizing non-reciprocal behavior through the design of heterogeneous acoustic, elastic, and electro-mechanical systems.  Technology that violates these fundamental rules opens the possibility of changing the standard operating procedures for measuring and utilizing acoustic and elastic waves. The work pairs these new concepts with robust materials design methodologies and additive manufacturing expertise to help redirect the nation?s technological advances in acoustics, structural vibration, ultrasonic inspection, seismic protection, and biomedical imaging.  Research efforts supported in this award specifically provide opportunities for underrepresented undergraduate students to participate in knowledge acquisition and exploration via multidisciplinary projects conducted in parallel at the collaborating institutions.

One approach to breaking time-reversal symmetry in linear systems to be considered is based on the dynamic coupling of momentum and strain using excitation on fast and slow time scales for acoustic and elastic media with spatially asymmetric microstructure.  Oscillations from a pump excitation provide a quasi-static momentum bias that enables non-reciprocal signal propagation.  Other routes to achieving non-reciprocal response include elastically nonlinear up-conversion from the drive frequency to higher harmonics.  Optimal damping and absorption in elastic waveguides, using an unexplored powerful relation between exceptional points and damping, will be examined. Other areas to be investigated include active control via shunted piezoelectric elements and hybrid time-varying circuits.  Materials design is at the center of the DEPARTED project with a view towards efficient design space exploration and employing state-of-the art additive manufacturing techniques to develop optimal microstructural topology of these structures.

por.por_cntn:
The project was focused on developing new insights into how mechanical wave motion, such as sound and elastic waves, can break classical restrictions, particularly reciprocity,  the fundamental "I see you - you see me" property of linear time-invariant systems.  The research used theoretical, computational and experimental methods to achieve non-reciprocal effects for acoustic and elastic waves.   Departures from linear time-reversibility was achieved using a variety of methods, including active mechanical elements, time modulation of physical properties, material nonlinearity,  and topological descriptions of system dynamics.  In the process the project members discovered, explained, and demonstrated multiple novel wave phenomena.  Among the major technical accomplishments are these:

  • Experimentally demonstrated a variety of mechanical wave effects with an active device made of piezoelectric sensor-actuator-pairs controlled with digital circuits.  The wave phenomena included perfect wave absorption, non-reciprocal wave transmission, and independent wavefront manipulation in transmitted and reflected directions (Figure 2).
  • Theoretically introduced a strategy to realize non-reciprocal propagation of Rayleigh surface waves using space-time modulated spring-mass oscillators on the surface.
  • Experimentally demonstrated a robust non-reciprocal sound transport phenomenon induced by the band tilting using a spinning acoustic tube with helical openings (Figure 3).
  • Demonstrated passive non-reciprocal wave effects theoretically using spring elements with different spring stiffness in compression and tension.  This bilinear property provides the underlying nonlinear mechanism but is also uniquely amplitude-independent, meaning that the output signal scales linearly with the input (Figure 1).
  • Developed a theoretical model involving topological invariants for acoustic one- and two-dimensional adiabatic pumping in acoustic cavity lattices with modulated channels, with experimental validation.
  • Performed dispersion analysis and experimental tests of nonreciprocal wave propagation in space-time modulated one-dimensional phononic crystals and locally resonant metamaterials composed of magnets and electrical coils.  
  • Developed a theoretical inverse design method to find the physical properties of scatterers such that a given incident wave is scattered in a preselected geometrical pattern. This allows the possibility of highly directional wave scattering.
  • Numerically and experimentally demonstrated in-plane edge and corner states in a mechanical kagome lattice.
  • Extended the concept of Willis materials, which couple stress and velocity, to piezoelectricity, showing that cross-coupling between the momentum and electric field emerges if the medium has broken inversion symmetry.
  • Demonstrated numerically and experimentally that a waveguide constructed with metasurfaces composed of repeated unit cells of tunable resonators will experience exceptional point behavior and the corresponding high attenuation rates at a finite amount of discrete frequencies.
  • Developed a graph-theoretic framework to enable the design and optimization of asymmetric and non-reciprocal metamaterial systems using statistical modeling and machine learning.
  • Performed inverse design of materials with asymmetric microstructure for non-reciprocal vibrations and wave phenomena using surrogate models and Bayesian Network Classifiers for design space exploration and parameter inversion.

The project enabled broader impacts though collaborative efforts across three campuses: Rutgers, UT Austin and U. Missouri.  Highlights include

  • 40+ peer-reviewed archival journal articles, including a review of the field of non-reciprocity in acoustic and elastic materials https://doi.org/10.1038/s41578-020-0206-0 co-authored with colleagues from other EFRI NEWLAW projects.  
  • A Special Issue of the Journal of the Acoustical Society of America containing focused on non-reciprocal and topological wave phenomena in acoustics was guest edited by the PI and co-PIs https://doi.org/10.1121/1.5119133
  • A 3-day Symposium on "Non-reciprocal and Topological Wave Phenomena in Solids and Fluids" organized by the project team, was held on the campus of Mizzou, May 2019.   
  • Seven students completed their PhD degrees all of whom went on to further careers in research.  Three postdoctoral fellows were mentored.
  • The project included Research Experiences for Undergraduates for six students at the three campuses.
  • The Structured Materials and Dynamics Lab at U. Missouri hosted hundreds of  middle and high school students for lab exhibits, plus alumni visits to demonstrate wave propagation control in materials.
  • At Rutgers graduate students developed a two-week research experience for high school students based on the project, involving over 20 students over several summers.
  • The UT Austin team mentored groups of FIRE (Freshman Introduction to Research in Engineering) students.  The students designed, fabricated, and 3D printed structures with asymmetric mechanical stiffness with the goal of demonstrating non-reciprocal systems.
